title: 108_s247
content: The Act titled "Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Amendments Act of 2003" retains the task force and introduces a prediction and response plan. Section 603 of the Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Amendments Act of 2003 is amended to include a Prediction and Response Plan. The President, in consultation with various stakeholders, must develop and submit a plan to Congress within 12 months to protect environmental and public health from harmful algal blooms. The plan will review prediction techniques. The President must develop a plan to predict and respond to harmful algal blooms, including innovative measures for prevention and mitigation. The plan must be published for public comment at least 90 days before submission to Congress. The Secretary of Commerce, in coordination with the Task Force, will provide Federal assistance to coastal States, Indian tribes, and local governments in implementing measures for harmful algal blooms. SEC. 4. LOCAL AND REGIONAL ASSESSMENTS. Section 603 of the Act is amended to include provisions for local and regional assessments of hypoxia and harmful algal blooms. The Secretary of Commerce, in coordination with the Task Force, will conduct these assessments as requested by coastal States, Indian tribes, and local governments. The assessments will focus on causes, impacts, alternatives, and costs related to hypoxia and harmful algal blooms in specific areas. The Task Force will conduct a scientific assessment of harmful algal blooms in the Great Lakes, including causes, consequences, and economic costs. The assessment will also include a research plan to coordinate Federal efforts in understanding Great Lakes harmful algal blooms. The Task Force will conduct a scientific assessment of harmful algal blooms in the Great Lakes to establish priorities for research and improve coordination among Federal agencies. The Task Force is required to submit a scientific assessment of hypoxia in US coastal waters, including the Great Lakes, every 5 years. The assessment will examine causes, consequences, and costs of hypoxia, evaluate policy actions, and review progress of Federal research programs. The Task Force is mandated to provide a scientific assessment of hypoxia in US coastal waters, including the Great Lakes, every 5 years. This assessment will cover causes, impacts, and costs of hypoxia, as well as evaluate policy actions and review Federal research programs to address gaps and improve coordination. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 605 of the Act is amended to allocate specific funding amounts for fiscal years 2004 to 2008, including $26,000,000 for 2004 and increasing amounts for subsequent years. Additional funding is designated for research programs in each fiscal year. Section 605 of the Act is amended to allocate funding amounts for fiscal years 2004 to 2008, with increasing amounts each year. The funding includes $2,000,000 for 2001, $6,000,000 for each year from 2004 to 2008, and varying amounts for research programs. The funding allocation for fiscal years 2004 through 2008 is increased to $3,000,000 annually for section 603(f) under the Act. The Senate passed S. 247.es on October 28, 2003, reauthorizing the Harmful Algal Bloom and Hypoxia Research and Control Act of 1998.
